utterances: Uh-oh.
What do you think?
Stomp the interviewer.
What do you think?
Well, I certainly think that at least part of what you're doing is reaching new audiences because you've changed your game a bit.
What do you think?
Oh.
Shifting up to (unintelligible) back so - so this is ping-pong, there's a little tennis going on.
I'm just trying to be a pin(ph), you know.
It's just whatever comes out as long as it's real and it's genuine, you know, and it's not contrive, you know, just coming up the music that I listen to with so many different styles.
You know, I was raised listening to The Police, Run DMC, you know, Houdini, the Mississippi Mass Choir to Celine Dion, you know?
I did a Christmas song on Josh Groban's new album.
You know what I mean?
So, you know, I'm a person who just enjoys music.
It sounds like you aren't satisfied with staying in a genre.
Well, you know, that's not what I'm walking around trying to do.
I don't have a passion any greater at standing at a local church preaching than I would standing at the Kennedy Center speaking.
It's like, for me, it's the same passion.
It really is the same passion, you know, because I really do what I do before an audience of one.
I'm - it's like every time I stand, you know, I'm standing to make my heavenly father happy.
And, you know, for me, somebody special for me who came from nothing, who was always told I was going to be nothing, whose momma told me, you know, that she wanted an abortion, you know.
Daddy gave me one thing and that was a haircut when his daddy died, when I was 7 years old.
And so that's why I'm so passionate about it.

If you met someone who hadn't listened to your music yet, who was going through a situation that was acute, whether it was just learning that you AIDS or learning that the person you loved was leaving you…
Yeah.
…and had built a life with.
Which track on your album would you send them to for solace?
I'll probably send them to the track ""Help Me Believe,"" track four.
The first few lines of the song says I want to believe but I'm having a hard time seeing past what I see right now.
And, you know, that's just - that's by the simple as I can say it.
(Soundbite of song, ""Help Me Believe"")
Unidentified Group #1: (Singing) Let me believe.
I wanna believe.
I'm not good over your wings.
Give me another chance.
It's hard to believe…
I want to talk about your aunt who helped you really get started as a musician.
Gertrude.
Yeah.
Tell me about her.
Yeah.
She biologically was my great, great, great-aunt.
And she gave me her name.
Her husband died when I was 2.
He died of cancer, and so she was 64 when she adopted me and I was 4 years old.
And they told me that her husband was the one that kind of play at the musical scene and he was Jack Franklin.
And they said he was a great musician and just a great man of God.

And they told me that when he was dying that he reached for me and he was calling for me and he said that I came to side of the hospital bed in the house and they said that he laid his hands on my head.
And Gertrude told me, you know, that she really believes that he was praying for his gift and his mantle to be on my life.
And Gertrude and I, we used to recycle old beer cans and newspapers to pay for my musical lessons.
We would stand inside - we'll stand outside Christmas and get government cheese sandwiches.
And, you know, the big block of government cheese.
They had a program at Texas called Good Fellows back in the '70s.
And you could apply if you have no income to get help and was really cool.

Because I still have this letter that Gertrude wrote to the newspaper asking to be put on the list because - and the letter says that she's a widow and she doesn't have money to be able to get her boy something for Christmas.
As a matter of fact, I'm saying now to you, you know, I've never let my kids see that letter.
And this Christmas, I want them to see that letter.
Wow.
I'm going to get that letter out.
And I'm going to show my kids because my kids go to private school.
They never had to want for nothing.
And I want their behinds to see we got to be grateful because of it.
And, you know, because Gertrude has been dead now for 17, 18 years, and so they never met her.
And it was her sacrifice that even allowed them now to live their life that their living.
Do you ever worry that your children will find it harder to walk a path of God because they're so privileged?
Not necessarily because they're privileged - I don't play that in my house.
It's like, you know, everybody in my house has to work for what they get.
My daughter, when she graduated from school even though it was a very good private school, she got a huge jeep and until we saw some grades she was not able to take it to college.
So, you know, I'm not trying to create little monsters and, you know, and I don't have a problem popping my little ones on their behind when they try to get too, you know, crazy.
And because there are a lot of kids I see in grocery stores and I was, like, ma'am, please, can I pop your child, you know?
You know?
(Soundbite of laughter)
You're even cussing at your momma out.
I was, like, please, here's my number, and if you need somebody to whip your kids, you can page me 24 hours.
I said I thought about starting a little side job and give me some cards and say, IWillWhipYourKids.com.
If you have some grocery store kids - if you're listening to this broadcast right now, we're going to give you a number after this broadcast.
And I will fly into your city and whip your kids.
Oh, my Lord.
Oh, my gosh.

What I am concerned about more than anything is not the whole issue of being privileged but what would their faith be, because having faith in our culture right now is coming so - it's not something that becomes to glue to the people on anymore.
Chicago.
I think that there's more people that travel here from out of town to visit and check out the city.
And it just seems like a cooler place for that versus San Francisco.
When you think about faith and pluralism, there's what going on in the U.S.
and then there's what's going on between the U.S.
and other places.
For example, in Israel and Palestine, you have two people who have deeply held beliefs.
And for many reasons, not just religious, those beliefs have sometimes become a barrier to peace.
Do you believe that belief itself, belief in a specific religion like Christianity, like Islam, can sometimes be a barrier to the very things, the very ideals that you hold dear?
Yes, they will be barriers.
And what has to happen is that my barriers shouldn't cause me to take a gun and kill you.
And I think that the challenge is that when we begin to shed blood and kill each other over those barriers.
That I, you know, believe in America that a person that believes in Islam should be able to drive down the street and not be afraid of being shot by a Christian.
That to take that person's life is just as much as a sin.
That there's a sin that killed that man based on what that man believes if that man lives in this country.
And if I want the freedom to believe that Jesus Christ is the son of God, then I have to allow that Muslim brother to believe in what he believes about Allah.
Before we let you go, what do you want to accomplish next?
Is there anything that you haven't done that you really want to do?

I am so, you know, just right now at the stage of my life of just really wanting to do what's been planned out for me to do and what's been divinely orchestrated for me to do because every good idea to me is a God idea, you know?
That's what I choose to live by.
And so whatever that is, I mean, you think I'm having a little future in politics, you think?
If you want it.
Can I do it?
Do you think I could do it?
You know, Obama might need a running mate.
And I don't think he would call Kirk.
I don't - I just don't see him calling me.
Time to put your name on the short list.
Yeah, there you go.
There you go.
(Soundbite of laughter)
There you go.
And since I'm already vertically challenged, that'd be a good for me to stand on (unintelligible).
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, Kirk Franklin, appreciated talking to you, and keep us in mind as you move forward through all your paths.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
Kirk Franklin's new album is ""The Fight of My Life.
